<p>
E. S. D. Lorenzo de Zavala
</p><p>
Tlalpan
</p><p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?city=jalapa" rel="city">Jalapa</a> February 26, <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?year=1829">1829</a>
</p><p>
My very esteemed friend and colleague,
</p><p>
Five post deliveries have transpired without my having had the pleasure of seeing a letter from you, despite the fact that ( ) owe two responses. What silence is this, dear friend? Is it possible that <a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=als" rel="me">Santa Anna</a> has displeased his friend Zavala? If some circumstance has been able to displease you, my honor assures you that it would have been an inadvertent act and by no means by desire. I know you too well, and I esteem you in the (full) valor that your patriotism, your talents, and your extraordinary knowledge deserve. If, dear friend, it is sensible to me that you have severed a relationship that is so pleasing to me [torn] ( ) to maintain. (Continue) it if were [torn] your pleasure, and indicate to me the error that I have committed in order to correct it.
</p><p>
My health finds itself almost entirely reestablished, and the business here has taken the turn that (we should) [torn] hope and we desired. Still something remains to ( ) 
</p><p>
[page missing]
</p><p>
to see it all at once; but this improvement cannot take effect, until I take the political and military authority of the State, a thing that will happen as soon as my banishment is lifted.
</p><p>
Do not fail to instruct me with your orders, whatever [torn] they may be, thus I will have the greatest pleasure in obeying them, your devoted friend who cares for you and kisses your hand.
</p><p>
<a href="http://www.familytales.org/results.php?tla=als" rel="me">Antonio Lopez de Santa Anna</a>
</p>
